com.pwnetics.helper
Class ItemDoubleAccumulator<K>

java.lang.Object
  com.pwnetics.helper.ItemDoubleAccumulator<K>
Type Parameters:
K - the type of object being used as the item
public class ItemDoubleAccumulator<K>
extends java.lang.Object

Use this to accumulate floating point values associated with objects and calculate simple statistics.

To accumulate objects, consider using add(Object, double); this will automatically add the value associated with the given object, introducing it into the collection if necessary. To query the accumulated value for an object, consider using get(Object); this will return the value associated with the given object. For objects that have not been added to an ItemCounter, the reported count is always null.

This class behaves differently from ItemCounter. When get(Object) is called for an object that was never added to ItemDoubleAccumulator, a "null" is returned. This allows ItemDoubleAccumulator to accumulate values that wind up at 0.0, and also start accumulating at 0.0 when new objects are introduced.

Author:
romanows

min

public ItemDoubleAccumulator.KeyValuePair min()
Returns the key/value pair with the lowest value (and secondarily with the "lowest" key). Not stable; if there are multiple "different" items that compare as equal (for example, if the keys don't implement Comparable), then it is possible for multiple calls to this method to return multiple answers.

Returns:
key/value pair with the lowest value, or if the accumulator is empty

variance

public java.lang.Double variance()
Get the sample variance of all item values in this collection. Use this variance if you desire an estimate of the variance of some population of items, of which the current ItemDoubleAccumulator contains only an incomplete sample. Otherwise, see variancePopulation().

Returns:
the sample variance of all item values, or null if empty.

variancePopulation

public java.lang.Double variancePopulation()
Get the population variance of all item values in this collection. Use this variance if you desire to know only the variance of the items in this ItemDoubleAccumulator only, otherwise see variance().

There is little difference between the sample and population variance when there are many distinct items. When there are few items, the difference is pronounced. In general, it is probably better to use the sample variance variance().

Returns:
the population variance of all item values, or null if empty.

sortByValueKey

public java.util.List<ItemDoubleAccumulator.KeyValuePair> sortByValueKey(boolean isAscending)
Returns a representation of the item-to-accumulated-value map with the keys sorted by their value, and then sorted by keys if the keys implement Comparable.

This sort is not stable; if there are multiple "different" items that compare as equal (for example, if the keys don't implement Comparable), then it is possible for multiple calls to this method to return various orderings.

Parameters:
isAscending - if true, will sort values and keys in ascending value; if false, will sort values and keys in descending value
Returns:
an unmodifiable sorted list
